item.title: Bowlby's Attachment Theory
item.description: Bowlby’s Attachment Theory [[attachment]] to a caregiver over the first year of life has important consequences throughout the life span.

item.title: Ecological Theory
item.description: Ecological Theory these place emphasis on the environmental factors Bronfenbrenner’s ecological theory Urie Bronfenbrenner proposed the ‘Ecological Systems Theory’ based on dynamic interactions that environments have on the child.

item.title: Erik Erikson's Psychosocial Stages
item.description: Erikson’s Psychosocial Theory like Freud’s theory, focuses on unconscious. But instead of sexual, focuses on social aspects connection, attribution, love, care

item.title: Ethological Theory
item.description: Ethological Theory says behavior is strongly influenced by biology and is tied to evolution characterized by critical or sensitive periods or specific time frames during which certain experiences can have a long-lasting influence

item.title: Information processing theory
item.description: 3. Information processing theory No structure or stages; continuous/gradual monitoring, manipulating, strategizing information #todo

item.title: Lorenz's Ethological Theory
item.description: Lorenz’s Ethological Theory, Imprinting Konrad Lorenz, a zoologist studied the behavior of greylag geese, which will follow their mothers as soon as they hatch

item.title: Mary Ainsworth's Attachment Theory
item.description: Mary Ainsworth’s Attachment Theory emphasized the importance of early relationships built on John Bowlby’s work [[Bowlby’s Attachment Theory]] Strange Situation assessment a researcher observes a child’s reactions when a mother briefly leaves her child alone in an unfamiliar room.

item.title: Heredity
item.description: Heredity, also called inheritance or biological inheritance, is the passing on of genetic material from parent to offspring The study of heredity in biology is called genetics

item.title: Late Adulthood
item.description: Physical Development Brain shrinks; 5-10% loss in mass Brain volume decreases (up to 15%) Immune System Decline Low level of protein linked to decrease in T cells

item.title: Middle Adulthood
item.description: Change in physical appearance skin begins to wrinkle and sag because of a loss of fat and collagen in underlying tissues hair thins and greys pigmentation Height and weight

item.title: Perinatal Period
item.description: During or around birth

item.title: Phases of Prenatal Development
Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love
item.description: Sternberg’s Triangular Theory of Love Intimacy Passion Commitment Non-love Liking/friendship ✔ Infatuated love ✔ Empty love ✔ Romantic love ✔ ✔ Companionate love ✔ ✔ Fatuous love ✔ ✔ Consummate love ✔ ✔ ✔

item.title: Developmental Research
item.description: Types of developmental research designs Cross-sectional design A cross-sectional study compares the behaviors of different age groups at a single time point.

item.title: Normative vs Idiographic
item.description: In [[Introduction to Life Span Development|Developmental Psychology]], patterns of change can be - Normative Idiographic focuses on what we share in common focuses on individual differences “normal” or typical changes different for everyone milestones for babies, for example individual variations outside of the range of normative dev and why

item.title: Midlife Crisis
item.description: occurs usually around 40 - 60 Identity, role, self-doubt regarding : professional life achievements family psychological aspects > physical aspects in terms of effect

item.title: Theories of Aging
item.description: [[Midlife Crisis| <- midlife crisis]] Theories of [[Senescence|Aging]] flowchart A(Theories of Aging)--B(Programmed Theories)--D(Programmed Longevity) A--C(Error Theories)--M(Wear and Tear) B--E(Endocrine) Why would aging be programmed into our genes?

item.title: Kagan's Behavioural Inhibition
item.description: Classifying [[Temperament]] in infants based on differences between shy, subdued, timid child and a sociable, extraverted bold child Inhibited Children -
Oestrogen - Ovulation thinning of mucus thickening of lining Progesterone - Menstrual Cycle thickening of mucus thinning of lining FSH - pituitary gland -

item.title: Assessing of newborns
item.description: APGAR Scale done at one and five minutes after A - Appearance P - Pulse G - Reflexes A - Activity

item.title: Birth Complications
item.description: Low birth weight - below 5.5 pounds - very low weight - extremely low weight - below 2.5 preterm infants small for date (aka small for gestational age)

item.title: Stages of birth
item.description: The Birth Process occurs in three stages First Stage Uterine contractions cause the woman’s cervix to stretch and open DILATE the cervix to an opening of ~10cm so baby can move from uterus to birth canal

item.title: Types of Birth
item.description: Natural aims to decrease pain by decreasing fear through education about childbirth and breathing techniques are used 1. Natural Vaginal

item.title: Theories of Human Development
item.description: flowchart LR A(Theories of Human Development) subgraph psychoanalytic B(Psychosocial Theory by Erik Erikson) C(Psychosexual by Freud) end subgraph cognitive E(Piaget's Cognitive Dev) F(Vygotsky's Social Cognitive) G(Information Processing Theory) end subgraph etho S(Lorenz's Ethological) V(Bowlby's Attachment) R(Ainsworth's Attachment) end A---etho A---Q(Urie's Ecological) A---psychoanalytic A---cognitive see also: [[Introduction to Life Span Development#Perspectives / Key issues in Lifespan Development|Key issues in Lifespan Development]]

item.title: Couvade Syndrome
item.description: etymology - the word couvade comes from the Breton word couver, which means to brood, hatch, or incubate Couvade syndrome is also called sympathetic pregnancy.

item.title: Emerging Adulthood
item.description: Emerging adulthood transition from adolescence to adulthood 18 - 25 characterized by experimentation and exploration Features Identity exploration, especially in love and work

item.title: Important Questions - Psychology
item.description: Define neonate and outline the patterns of development What are the three basic [[Temperament]]al styles Discuss the importance of friendship and peer relationships during adolescence Define language and biological influence on [[Language Development]] DIscuss types of reflexes in infants Stages of language development Describe the physical changes that occur during puberty Marcias Identity Statuses Explain components of language 9M

item.title: Infancy, Childhood, and Adolescence
item.description: Neonate Neonate -> Infant between 0 and 28 days/4 weeks learns feeding patterns aka newborn Physical Development Gross Motor Fine Motor Patterns of growth Cephalocaudal Pattern

item.title: Language Development
item.description: something Rules of Language Phonology Morphology Syntax Semantics Pragmatic Child Directed Speech Language Acquisition Device (LAD) - [[Noam Chomsky]] Stages of Language Development Cooing Babbling One Word Speech Telegraphic Speech Whole sentence [[Broca’s Area]] [[Wernicke’s Area]]

item.title: Life Span Development introduction
item.description: Life Span Development development from conception to death lifelong progressive orderly what is development? Development is the pattern of progressive, orderly

item.title: Marcia's Identity Statuses
item.description: Identity Diffusion Identity Foreclosure Identity Moratorium Identity Achievement based on [[Theories of Human Development#Erikson’s Psychosocial Theory|Erikson’s Psychosocial Theory]]

item.title: Moral Development Theory
item.description: by Lawrence Kohlberg [[Heinz Dilemma]] social and cultural norms LEARNT 3 levels - Preconventional (5-9) Stage 1. Obedience and Punishment

item.title: Self Concept Development
item.description: Self Concept Definition Attributes, characteristics, what makes us us. physically, emotionally, socially, spiritually overall idea we have about who we are
